articles.headline: U.S. Won’t Prosecute in States That Allow Medical Marijuana
articles.snippet: People who use marijuana for medical purposes and those who distribute it to them will not face federal prosecution, provided they act according to state laws.
articles.abstract: People who use marijuana for medical purposes and those who distribute it to them will not face federal prosecution, provided they act according to state laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  People who use marijuana for medical purposes and those who distribute it to them should not face federal prosecution, provided they act according to state law, the Justice Department said Monday in a directive with far-reaching political and legal implications.
articles.byline: By David Stout and Solomon Moore

articles.headline: Apple’s Profit Climbs 47% as Sales Gain
articles.snippet: Strong sales of the iPhone and Macintosh computers helped Apple post strong gains while rivals still struggle.
articles.abstract: Strong sales of the iPhone and Macintosh computers helped Apple post strong gains while rivals still struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple, in its recent history, has overcome nearly every obstacle thrown its way. Now it has surpassed another: the burden of high expectations.

articles.headline: ‘You Have Atomic Bombs, but We Have Suicide Bombers.’
articles.snippet: The Taliban fighters who kidnapped David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghans were guided by a strident belief that the United States was waging a war against Islam. The third installment in Mr. Rohde’s account of his captivity.
articles.abstract: The Taliban fighters who kidnapped David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghans were guided by a strident belief that the United States was waging a war against Islam. The third installment in Mr. Rohde’s account of his captivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A NERVOUS-LOOKING Pakistani soldier pointed a rocket-propelled grenade at our pickup truck in late January. The Taliban guard beside me loaded his rifle and ordered me to put a scarf over my face. A group of Pakistani civilians standing nearby moved out of the way, anticipating a firefight.

articles.headline: New York Times Moves to Trim 100 in Newsroom
articles.snippet: The newspaper is offering buyouts, but layoffs will follow if an insufficient number fail to sign up, employees were told on Monday.
articles.abstract: The newspaper is offering buyouts, but layoffs will follow if an insufficient number fail to sign up, employees were told on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times plans to eliminate 100 newsroom jobs  about 8 percent of the total  by year’s end, offering buyouts to union and nonunion employees, and resorting to layoffs if it cannot get enough people to leave voluntarily, the paper announced on Monday.

articles.headline: Wall St. Giants Reluctant to Donate to Democrats
articles.snippet: Only a half-dozen donors from big financial firms that received bailouts are attending a fund-raiser on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Only a half-dozen donors from big financial firms that received bailouts are attending a fund-raiser on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Wall Street giants that received a financial lifeline from Washington may have no compunction about paying big bonuses to their dealmakers and traders. But their willingness to deliver “thank you” gifts to President Obama and the Democrats is another question altogether.

articles.headline: Thin Line Separates Insider Trading and Research
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s relentless quest for an edge in trading stocks has complex boundaries, making insider trading allegations difficult to prove.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s relentless quest for an edge in trading stocks has complex boundaries, making insider trading allegations difficult to prove.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most precious commodity on Wall Street is information, and savvy players will do almost anything for it.

articles.headline: The Race to Save Lehman Brothers
articles.snippet: In this excerpt from a new book, Lehman’s chairman reaches out in several directions to find relief for his sinking firm.
articles.abstract: In this excerpt from a new book, Lehman’s chairman reaches out in several directions to find relief for his sinking firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2008, two months before Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the firm's chairman, was continuing his desperate efforts to find a lifeline. They had begun in March, shortly after the demise of Bear Stearns, when Mr. Fuld called the legendary investor Warren E. Buffett seeking a capital infusion, to no avail. Lehman had raised money elsewhere, but that didn't help for long, and its condition again was worsening.

articles.headline: Vatican Bidding to Get Anglicans to Join Its Fold
articles.snippet: A formal structure would oversee the conversion to Roman Catholicism of Anglicans uncomfortable with their church’s acceptance of female priests and openly gay bishops.
articles.abstract: A formal structure would oversee the conversion to Roman Catholicism of Anglicans uncomfortable with their church’s acceptance of female priests and openly gay bishops.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY  In an extraordinary bid to lure traditionalist Anglicans en masse, the Vatican said Tuesday that it would make it easier for Anglicans uncomfortable with their church’s acceptance of female priests and openly gay bishops to join the Roman Catholic Church while retaining many of their traditions.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Laurie Goodstein
